social_posts.post_text:
I wrote this caption when I was in Bali last week & even though I’m back in Singapore, I want to share this with you.

So, please imagine that I’m narrating this to you from Bali.🌴

——
I’m sitting in this beautiful coffee shop in Bali, overlooking the rice fields …& remembering how I was resisting this vacation.

I’d been so tied up with client work that the podcast took a break, I was exhausted & you already know, I was burned out. Like sizzling 🔥

And to take a vacation in the midst of that, felt uneasy. I could use that time to work.

But also, if I kept staying busy with daily tasks, how would I ever stop the sizzle aka get out of the burnout.🤷🏻‍♀️

I had to do something different & the best way to do something different is to not do what you usually do.🫵🏼

Here in Bali, I’m not at my desk or shooting for a client or creating content.
Instead, I’m at this coffee shop, shooting my delicious breakfast & creating a lil space to breathe & reflect.☘️

I’m hopeful that these few days in Bali will be a breath of fresh air.

Being in the same environment did not help me get out of this burnout phase, which is why, this trip was necessary.✈️

I don’t expect to have complete clarity when I return but I do hope to find renewed energy & inspiration during this break.🌼

Sipping this Bali coffee, I’m glad that I’m breaking away from the usual & doing things differently. I’m certain it will give different results.💛

But I do hope that I’m still sizzling when I return 🔥..
.. not from the burnout but from tanning on the beach
🤩 ☀️

Love from Bali
DJ ✌🏼

This version of eton mess with cherry & yogurt reminded me of the delicious Asian style eton mess we had at a beautiful restaurant as we celebrated our 11th wedding anniversary this past weekend.🥂

As we rollercoaster-ed into the 11th year of marriage, I just couldn’t believe how we’d made it so far.

I’ve known the husband since 6th grade & still don’t understand how 2 people, so completely different, can be so similar.🤨

Last week when we were in Bali, I’d start my day with high-energy workouts or running. It relaxed & refreshed me.🏃🏻‍♀️
The husband would sit with his coffee, book & begin reading at 6am everyday. That relaxed & refreshed him.📝

While I sat in the beautiful cafes & felt inspired, he watched the Bali rain & found inspiration in those moments of stillness.🌤️

While I enjoyed Bali’s sunny days sipping mimosas at brunch, his ultimate elixir was the local jamu herbal drink.🍹

We might have found our energies in different ways but both of us loved the warmth of the locals, freaked out on food, went crazy on funky scooter rides & marvelled at the glowing sunsets.💛

I feel that in life’s eton mess, one partner is always the meringue & other, the whipped cream. Both so different but pair perfectly together.😉

For us, I’m the meringue & he’s the yogurt.
We clash. We argue. We create a mess.
We also accept. We respect & create sweet memories.

I’ve known him for almost 30 years now - I guess, that’s what they call “eton-al” love.😍✌🏼

In life’s eton mess, are you the meringue or the cream? 😅
.
.
.
.

Who’s been busy baking cookies?
Not me 😛
Truth is.. I can never get cookies right.
I’d rather travel in December than bake …but this year is different. We are taking it slow & staying put in Singapore - almost.

But that doesn’t mean I won’t be reminiscing about good ol’ travel days esp. when I killed the husband - almost..🤭
.
—— In 2015 we took a trip to Norway to see the Northern lights, in the middle of peak winters.
We were to change 4 flights to get to Tromso, a small city near the North Pole - almost.🤓

We landed in Alta, Norway & were getting ready for the last flight when the Husband said, “It’s beautiful. Let’s take a walk.”
We had a bit of time, so we stepped outside.
And then he said, “The lights are so pretty. Let’s take a drive.”🚗

“What? We’ll miss our flight”
But seeing the spontaneous husband, I was like, “To hell with the flight”.😉

We got into a taxi & the husband asked the cabbie to drive to a location I had no clue about.

At first it was lovely but then I began to get anxious. I asked to turn back but the husband refused.
The spontaneity was not fun anymore.🤬

After 10 mins, my anger was outta control & I was ready to kill the husband when the cabbie interrupted,
“Your hotel, Sir.”

😮 I looked outside & right in front was an ice hotel dazzling away on that polar night.✨✨

Turns out the husband had planned a surprise detour on our way to Tromso - a night at an ice hotel in Norway.😅

In minutes I wrapped myself in warm layers, found a broken sledge outside, sat in it, rode along the snowy streets, made the Husband sit in it & violently threw snowballs at him.👻 (swipe to see)

The evening was spent by the fire, eating cookies - the perfect combo of December bakes & travel for me.😍

— I’ve told the husband, no cookies for him this year until I get another surprise. 
…but I think he’s totally taking advantage of that cuz he knows how I bake cookies — violently like throwing snowballs.😜

What do you prefer in December- baking cookies or traveling? 💛
.
.
.
.
.

As I was shooting this Gluten-free chocolate cherry christmas cake for @the_wholekitchen, those layers of ganache packed with cherries inspired me to shoot like the cake photos I’d seen in my mom’s cookbooks while growing up.🤩

My mom has a huge collection of books coz she’s a voracious reader.. ahem much unlike me 🫢
...And amongst those thrillers & biographies in her library, there’s a whole section of cookbooks.

Now, as a chubby, food-loving kid, it was obviously my favourite section.👻
.
On afternoons when mom would nap, I’d quietly drag a stool, stand on it, raise my heels & reach high for those cookbooks.📚

Few of them would come tumbling down, few would bounce on my head before taking the fall but out of all, there was one that I’d tightly hold on to - a large square cookbook, my favourite. 🟨

I’d reach directly for it and safely bring it down, slowly picking all the others from the floor.

I’d then line up the books neatly on the bed. Then lie myself down on the bed too, on my cushioned belly & bring the big square book in front.📖

There.. that would be start of the most blissful afternoon.😌

I’d drown in the gorgeous photography, get curious about new ingredients & just drool endlessly.😍

I think I’d read more cookbooks than course books as a kid.
But hey, isn’t that coming in handy now 😛

Honestly, right from the beginning, my love for cookbooks & food photos was telling me what would bring me the most joy.
It was right in front of me, staring me in the face the whole time…. But I chose to ignore it.😯

And now that I’m finally on that path, I wish I’d got here sooner.❤️

As we count our blessings at the end of the year, I’m soo grateful to be where I belong - in the world of food & photography.📸

…And to be able to make a living out of it..
…well, I call that - the cherry on top.😉

What are you grateful for this year?💛
.
.
.

A very happy new year with these figs canapés with mulberries, raisins & rosemary smeared with dome de boulogne cheese and drizzled with homemade moscato syrup ❤️

How was your first day of the year?
Did it feel promising, like yeah, this is going to be THE year!
Well, mine was exactly Not like that.👎🏼

On the first day of the new year we were grappled with the pain of our unwell daughter.😔

Instead of welcoming the new start, the day was spent cleaning up after projectile throw ups - projectiles strong enough to put Olympian javelin throwers to shame.🤮

The day started off perfectly with the Daddy taking off for a work thing while us ladies dressed up, the daughter put on fake lipstick and we headed for a girly lunch.👠

Just 3 years+, she’s miss Chatty Cathy.
Between the carbonara, gelato, conversations about Harry Styles and the Japanese guy she finds utterly cute, her smart mommy also slipped in a lil hint about how mommy is more fun than Daddy and she must always vote for mommy 😛.

That daddy’s girl had almost converted when she suddenly began to feel sick — the start to the not-so-great start to the year — thereon, she was miserable.💔

My heart broke seeing her & I was very disheartened by the unexpected start to the year but realised...

..It doesn’t matter if our year didn’t start on a high note, if it wasn’t buzzing with fireworks or loud music, if we weren’t surrounded by family or friends or clinking glasses or covered in bling.

..None of that matters cuz none of that decides what our year will be like.

If you had a smooth start, keep that pace and positivity.💛
If you had a rough start like me, believe that it can only get better.✌🏼

You can still kill it. 
You can still ace it. 
You can still win it. 
Don’t let tough beginnings derail you.
It doesn’t matter how you start a race. It matters how you finish.💪🏼

The only strong part about my start to the year was the speed of the projectiles.😅

So, I’m focussed on the finish now - a strong finish, smeared with cheese & drizzled with moscato syrup.
Hope it comes true & isn’t just a “fig-ment” of my imagination.😜

How was your start to the year? Smooth or rough?💛
.
.
.
#deliciousfood

Food that is relatively flat & has low height, like cookies or chips, can be difficult to work with. Right?😅

How to make them not look flat? How make them look 3-D? How to bring depth & storytelling to them?

That’s the reason we often see photos with cookies stacked vertically, shot in the straight-on camera angle.
But if you’re tired of seeing and creating the same sort of photos for flat food, try this next time.📸

It’s a simple technique of overlapping, adding texture & using a different camera angle.🥸

🍪 Overlapping : creates shadows underneath and adds depth - the biggest challenge with flat food, right?

🍪 Crumbs : bring texture and convey the flavour. But careful not to overdo the crummy bits 😅

🍪 3/4th camera angle - brings the 3-D impact & more depth to the photo. This styling works for a top-down angle as well but the 3/4th angle adds an extra dimension to the photo.

Flat food can be challenging to shoot but it also opens an opportunity for us to create out of the box.🤩

Explore the technique of overlapping, play with the 3/4th angle and create your unique photos 💪🏼… break away from the usual stacked styling because that’s Not the way the cookie crumbles. 😅
.
.

.

For me, the loop of Success looks something like this —
Run - fall - stand - repeat 😅

When we see a blogger write a best-seller or a photographer receive an award or a runner win a race — we think, “how lucky”.

But winning is anything but luck.👎🏼

That one moment of winning is made of hundreds of hours of practice, blood, sweat and discipline.💪🏼

Look at singers & sportspersons - early mornings, daily practice, restricted diet, showing up every single day no matter rain or shine. Woah!😮

I feel so inspired by them. Maybe that’s why Rocky is one of my favorite movies.😋

It has taught me if we continue to do what’s right, success is a guarantee.✌🏼
Cuz there’s nothing like instant success.🚫

If your photography is not where you want it to be, keep practicing everyday and don’t stop even if it feels difficult. Every click takes you closer.📷

If finding clients in your photography business seems tough, keep trying, try new ways to reach them, try reaching out to new clients. Every pitch takes you one step forward 💰

It’s not easy for anyone.

No runner wins a race by running one day - it takes time & training.🥇

No photographer gets accolades when they just pick up a camera - it takes years to build technique.📸

No one gets fit by eating healthy one day - it takes continuous good habits.🥦

Every single fall
Every single fail
Every single rejection
Every single tear..
.. is taking you one step closer to winning.🏆

No matter how tough it feels right now, keep doing what you do because winning is not about that one moment. It’s about the hundreds of hours that go into creating that moment.⏳

As you keep trying, tell yourself, “I’m not going to give up because I’m creating those hundreds of hours.” 👊🏼
.
.

.

When I took this photo of lavender hummus - hummus with olives sprinkled with lavender oil & salt - I was in pain (you’ll know why) but also buzzing with creativity.🤩

It wasn’t a client project & so, I just went with the creative flow, floating to where it led me.
And I remember feeling so pumped & thinking, “I have to do this more often.”✌🏼

Ha! It’s as if the universe heard its own version of it.😵‍💫

So, while I’ve been photographing a lot over the past year, it’s mostly been for commercial projects.

My personal projects are waiting for me with the same patience with which I peeled the skin of every chickpea for this smooth hummus texture.🤪

Let me ask -
When was the last time you immersed yourself in photography for the sheer joy of it?

When was the last time you photographed just for fun?

When was the last time you went with your creative flow & the results were beautiful?

I’m pretending to ask you but I’m actually asking myself. 🥸

You know that itching feeling, when all you want is to pick up the camera & spend hours getting jiggy with it 📸....but time and life get in the way?

I’m there now. Itching to photograph for fun.🥹

This photo of lavender hummus reminded me that personal work is so important.

It builds skill but also fills our soul.
It reminded me of the joy of getting lost between lights & highlights.
It reminded me of what it feels like to be struck by sparks of creativity.
It reminded me of how simple joys can enrich our lives & nurture our art.

Sigh ..💛

Well…ahem.. after that reminder & my big speech it only makes sense that I pick my camera & click for the sheer joy of it
-- a joy I’d forgotten but reminded of by the memory of peeling 1000 boiled chickpeas only to get that smooth texture for that one photo.

Pain can be such a good reminder of joy. Right?🤪

When was the last time you photographed just for fun? 🙌🏼
. 
.
.

I was once working with a brand & had to photograph their yellow bowls with food.
I struggled for 2 days before understanding that using colours in food photography might look easy but can be tricky as heck.😰

It looks simple but the combination of camera + lights + colour is whole different ballgame.

After that yellow-bowl-shoot, I realised that when it comes to colours - it’s best to keep it simple. Just like life 😅.

Too many colours only overcomplicate the process & often, don’t even give good results.

Sometimes, Monochrome or 1 color only can be hard to work with so, selecting 2 or max. 3 colours really works well.✌🏼
.
.
Here’s what happens when we work with a limited palette -

👊🏼 Powerful impact - The eye is not distracted by too many colors and the photo instantly creates a powerful impact, exactly what we want our photos to do.

⏰ Saves Time - We don’t spend hours struggling to make the colours work. Limiting to 2 colors makes decision taking easier.

📌 Strong Story - Because the props, backdrop and food stay within the limited palette, it ties the photo cohesively & brings stronger storytelling to the frame.

💪🏼 Builds skill - Staying within a given set of colours teaches the creative muscle to work within boundaries. It is esp. helpful when working with brands.

In food photography, “less is more” really works well when choosing colours.
It doesn’t matter which 2 colours are selected, a limited palette always creates a POW effect 💥.

And when this becomes a habit rather than a practice out of the blue, your photos get better, your competition turns green with envy and you’re tickled pink yourself. Ha! 😉

Do you find it tricky to work with different colours?🤓
.
.

.

If anyone in the world tells you that making cauliflower crust for pizza is easy, first off, don’t believe them.
And second off, dont go trying to test it out to see if they were right.✋🏼

In the name of prepping the crust, it is a lower arm, upper arm, forearm & every other arm workout.😵‍💫

It is a game of patience, pushing you to the edge to see how far you’re willing to go for a “healthy” pizza.

It also crazily twists your creative muscle to turn an off-white cauliflower dough into colourfully irresistible.😰

It is a trap, boss.🪤
Don’t go that route unless you’re looking for biceps, a medal for completing mission impossible or a degree in pale food photography.

Haha, just kidding.😁

Not really. That pizza dough was a real pain in the ..ahem.🥸

But this shot was a high point for sure. 
They say, what doesn’t kill you makes you stronger.🙄

Squeezing buckets of water from grated cauliflower to make it dough-worthy dry definitely killed me.
I could see my muscles getting bigger with every squeeze, heart rate going up and breathing getting faster.
.. perhaps from frustration.😠

That watery, bare coloured cauliflower got to me & I was furious for venturing into the world of healthy pizzas.
I was angry .. so angry that my face turned red.

Red.. red .. more red!!😡

And there it was. My inspiration for this colour palette.

My fury had led me to a breakthrough.😝

I instantly visualised the palette, put a composition together, sweared at the cauli dough & sang saucy songs to the red tomatoes.🙃

Red had saved the day.❤️

And that my friend, is what happens when you go down the path of cauliflower crust.😅

To all the food bloggers who want to hurl a shoe at me or say I’m wrong, dont forget that I now have  Schwarzenegger muscles thanks to you.
Try me!😛

But to everyone else, moral of the story - inspiration can come from anywhere.
Sometimes from creativity & sometimes from the fury of wringing water out of a cloth for hours in the attempt to turn a vegetable into a pizza.🤪
.
.
.
#yum #deliciousfood #foodphotographer #lovefood #plantbased #lifeandthyme #farmtofork #foodphoto #foodstyling #homecooking #pizzalover #healthychoices

Right before my first restaurant photoshoot, I was convinced I was going to screw it up. 
I was sure something would go wrong & the shoot would flop.👎🏼

Well, did something go wrong? 
Heck yes it did. Majorly. 

Did I screw it up? 
Nopes, I salvaged the situation & turned it around. 

Was the shoot a flop?
It was a hit.✌🏼

When a situation is too good to be true, we find it difficult to visualise ourselves being successful in it. We begin to imagine scenarios that will NOT let us perform.🚫

A restaurant shoot for a newbie photographer was too good to be true.
Instead of imagining myself rocking the shoot, my only thoughts were,
“what if I can’t get the light right or style the food?”

I could only think of failing, flopping & falling.😨

We never say, “yeah, I can do this.”
Instead, we stay in the circle of self-doubt, giving ourselves 1001 reasons why we are not good enough.⁉️

This happens because we underestimate ourselves.
We think that an opportunity like a fancy restaurant shoot is “bigger” than us.
We even go to the extent of thinking that we are lucky to have landed it & the client is almost doing us a favour by hiring us.

Those thoughts are natural but damage our confidence.💔

Imagine if all those thoughts flipped and we gave ourselves 1001 reasons why we ARE good enough.✨✨

How would that change our performance?
It would sky rocket our performance. It would make us believe in ourselves.

And if we did get stuck in a tough situation, that faith would guide us.💪🏼

Always remember…
You’re more capable than you think. 
You get hired because you HAVE what it takes.
No one is doing you a favour & it is definitely not luck.
You have to ability to handle any situation. 🧨

Just keep self-doubt at bay.
Self-doubt is the enemy of growth.
It is the enemy of the best version of you.🫵🏼
.
.

.

On Valentine’s Day, I was researching quick desserts & saw that sweets weren’t really tempting me.
My mind kept going to the savoury side. Biryani😅

Chocolate & sweet treats are usually the first choice on Valentine’s Day but for me, Biryani is the highest expression of love.
Biryani is my love language. 😂

This is my mom’s chicken Biryani recipe & my favourite Biryani.😍

Once we had friends over for dinner & someone asked, “what would you choose as your last meal?”

At first I said, “kebabs”.
But quickly corrected, “ No no. Biryani.”🤟🏼

Biryani is not only love but a huge inspiration in my life.
Yep, Inspiration.😁

Tell me, do you set goals for yourself? 
Any goal? Like cleaning a cupboard or exercising 3 times a week or pitching to a client. 

Big or small, we all set goals. 
But how do we get ourselves to achieve that goal?🤷🏻‍♀️

I use the carrot technique. 🥕 
I set a tempting reward for myself for every goal.

I tell myself, “If I clean the cupboard, I’ll have space for new clothes. Ooh!”
“If I lose a few inches, I’ll fit into that dress I bought when I was 22.”😬

Haha! I dangle a carrot aka reward for every goal.🏆 

I like to run 2-3 times a week. My knees pain and my soles give way but I still run. Why?🤪

If you’re thinking, “for fitness?”
Yes, but also for the reward.

My dangling carrot for staying fit is the most friggin rich plate of biryani.😂
To me, running means earning my Biryani.

When I run I hear the seductive voice of Biryani saying in my ear, “you know you want me.”💋

Biryani keeps me fit, motivated & makes me reach my goals with enthusiasm.. & a bit of drool.
It is my love, biggest inspiration, motivator & guide.🤭

We all need a dangling carrot to push us sometimes. Choosing what we love as our “carrot”even if it is a leg of chicken works wonders.✌🏼

My huge realisation on Valentine’s Day was that sweets might be the popular choice but nothing has me wrapped around its finger like a spoonful of Biryani.😛

Which food says to you, “you know you want me.”😁

.
.
.

Freshly rolled croissants made with exquisite French butter by the most skilful croissant chef - was one of my shoots for @tiongbahrubakery 🙌🏼

I was to photograph the best croissants in town but not in a million years had I imagined how it would happen.😅

Taking notes during the client briefing, all sounded fine until they said, “oh ya, we will be shooting in our central kitchen.”

A few months into commercial photography, I was almost squeaky new.
The mention of shooting in a kitchen made me nervous but I couldn’t show it. 
So, I cleared my throat & replied with confidence, “sure”.😎

Sweating, thought to myself, “God save me.”🫢

Few days before to the shoot, I saw photos of the kitchen and finalized a space for the photoshoot.📌

Now, photos are different from reality.

On the day, walking into the kitchen, I broke into cold sweat.😧
The space was very different from what I’d imagined. Some areas were smaller, some larger.

My heart was racing and I kept doubting whether I’d be able to execute the shoot.😰

To begin, we carried the giant softbox on our shoulders carefully over the chocolate tarts and lemon cake, making sure nothing was disturbed & fitted it tightly between 2 counters.
Phew!😨

Next, the chef was positioned, croissants laid out & eggs cracked but as soon as I took out my favourite lens, it all flopped. The space was too tight.
I couldn’t shoot the angle and composition I wanted.😓

I had to do something. Quick.
Improvisation - changed lens & camera angle. New composition.🙇🏻‍♀️

With a squished softbox, the laptop resting on empty egg crates, tethering cable sitting on discarded dough, me standing on a chair breathing its last, balancing myself in a 2’ wide alley with one foot hanging in the air, using all my camera & yoga skills -  is how this photoshoot happened.🤩

Truth is, there’ll always be tough situations no matter how pro we are.

We can’t let our nerves take over. We need to do(ugh) what’s possible, think on our feet & sometimes even stand on one, if needed.😂

What’s been your toughest photoshoot so far?💛
.
.
.

Wish you a very happy Holi with this Meetha Paan (betel leaf) Ice Cream from @mrs.Plumps.💛

Just like we have a spirit animal, I feel Holi is my “spirit festival”.
Bright colours, pumping music, drunken drinks, enticing sweets, loud laughs & downright high energy - totally my favourite festival.✌🏼

And paan is definitely a flavour of this festival.💚

I love meetha (sweet) paan but connoisseurs eat the non-sweet version with betel nuts, chuna (slaked lime paste) etc.. You need a mouth of steel to be a true paan connoisseur.😛

It’s not for everyone & definitely not me..
I’ve shared this story before but I’ve to again cuz paan has scarred me for life.😅

My grandad was a connoisseur. A paan snob, he made his own. An avid eater, he ate paan after meals & in-between too. In fact, He had a guy bring him the freshest leaves every morning.💪🏼

Whenever I’d visit, Grandad made me a meetha paan - it was our thing.🙌🏼

5 years old, I’d sit on the sofa, stretch out my tiny legs on a footstool & chew paan like a cow chews the cud.😜

One morning the paan guy delivered the leaves & chuna for the day. I saw it being kept in the fridge. 

Grandad wasn’t around so I decided to help myself - opened the fridge, saw the top leaf rolled as paan & stuffed it in my mouth.🥸

Few chews in, I felt a burn & then it got worse. Felt like fire. I spat it🤮 but the burn continued.😫

The loud crying gathered the family & there was panic.

Turns out, what I had eaten was NOT paan. It was chuna (slaked lime) - chuna that grandad needed for the ENTIRE day.😱
It was rolled in a betel leaf & I thought it was paan.😐

Imagine eating a spoonful of calcium hydroxide (Chuna) - exactly what I had.🥵

Holy blistering barnacles!
What followed were crazy mouth blisters.😫
It took days & loads of ice cream to recover but the fear of picking the wrong paan has stayed since.🥸

Thats’s why I think paan ice cream is so perfect cuz Holi might be my spirit festival but when it comes to picking up fresh paan, even my spirit stays away.😝

Happy Holi 🤩✌🏼✨
.
.
.

“How do I find my style?” - One of the first questions we are posed with in food photography & a constant pursuit throughout our journey.📸

I started a photography business without a clue that every food photographer was expected to “find their style.”😦

I photographed what I liked, how I liked.
Ignorance is bliss for a reason.🤭

As I got in to the industry, all I saw around was hot-shot photographers asking, “Have you found your style?”

It made my head spin.
I didn’t know if I had found my style. It made me nervous. Was I missing something?😰

And Just because I didn’t have an answer, I doubted myself, thinking I wasn’t a real photographer cuz I wasn’t speaking the same lingo.

It crushed my confidence.💔
My photography took a hit. I thought I was doing it wrong. I needed to create like the others, follow the same steps as them and that would lead me to my style.

It did lead me.
It led me to a style that was confused, difficult to relate to & so not me.🤯

And that’s when the bell rang in my head. I already had a style.✌🏼
It was what I was already creating. I didn’t need to “find it” cuz it was there all along.
It was the photography that reflected my personality & was 💯 me.

Just because you’re not speaking, thinking or creating like the rest, doesn’t mean you’re doing it the wrong way.
It means you’re doing it YOUR way. It’s a good thing & the fastest way to establish your style.🪝

And just like you’re not the same person you were 5 years ago, your style won’t stay the same either. It will change with you 💛

The pursuit continues but as long as you create original work from a place that is true to you, you’ll always have a unique style. 💪🏼

Why be anyone else when you can be you? 😎
.
.

.

I loved creating this photo of Sourdough with pepperoni, olives & peppers on this brick backdrop.📸

Here’s why -

When was the last time you said, “I love my life. I’m so happy. This is exactly where I wanted to be.”

I said that to myself was a few weekends ago.🤓

You know I was an architect in my past life & left a 6-figure salary to follow my love for food photography. (PS - I loved healthcare Architecture & still do).✌🏼

Few weekends ago, I bumped into an old colleague at a party, we worked together a decade ago - a blast from the past.⌛️

We reminisced about the crazy, insane, intense days.
He told me stories of the ex-colleagues and how life had turned out for them.

Some were in status quo, some successful & some victims of corporate foul play.😓

Hearing those stories, I began visualising what my life would’ve been as an architect.
I thought I’d feel shaky hearing success stories, but the more I listened, the more secure I felt.🙏🏼

Running a business means taking risks everyday but a flashback of the corporate life made me realise that I’d pick risk over stability any day.

Some people thrive in the corporate world but I was not made for it.🥸

I realised that living in office structures, working like the world expected, confirming to norms and performing for managers was holding me back from what I was actually meant for.📷

Meeting this blast-from-the-past-colleague made me grateful for how the universe had aligned for me.✨

I walked out of that party happy as a baby, thrilled to be a photographer & entrepreneur, living the life I was destined for.

If you’ve ever felt shaky about your career choices, remember it takes courage to follow your heart.

Corporate, business or art, do what makes you happy. Live in whatever way that makes you say - “I love my life!” 🤟🏼

Puran Poli (sweet flatbread) by @from_the_pan with chilli sauce from @foodsbyri is a perfect sweet spicy combo to pair with chai (tea)
.. it’s like a disco dance in your mouth.🕺🏻🕺🏻

But how much effort do you think it takes to bring out that disco dance in a photo, to create that food story in a visual?📸

Few years ago I was catching up with an old friend who also had an interest in photography. 🏔️

Over a glass of wine, I was telling her how I was taking baby steps to understand the subtleties of food photography. 😊

But as I spoke, I saw her expressions changing.
It went from frown to confusion to an unconvinced sigh.🤔

I thought I’d offended her. Not a fan of misunderstandings, I asked directly if something was wrong.😥

She cleared her throat & said, “Why is food photography any different?
Once you know how to use a camera, it’s pretty standard… Like any other kind of photography.”

I smiled.😅

I totally saw her point cuz food photography looks simple on the surface but is not quite so in reality.🥸

While each kind of photography comes with its own challenges, I find food more challenging cuz it needs us to create a scene from scratch.✏️

Food can’t put on makeup to look pretty for the camera.
Dishes don’t have expressions like people.
Meals aren’t naturally beautiful like landscapes.
Food doesn’t race like sports cars to look thrilling.
😝

Food photographers need to make food do all that & more.
We need to create compositions that make food look appetising, emotional, striking and thrilling.
It can take hours to create just ONE photo.
That’s why our job is a tad bit different.
& that’s why we are crazy about it.😍

As I explained, she got it.💛

Food photography is more than putting food in front of the camera & clicking the shutter. It takes vision, feelings and energy to weave visual stories.

..but when it takes shape, the effort is so worth it.💪🏼

It feels like a sweet-spicy celebration.. almost like a disco dance of creativi-tea 🤩

Do you agree?💛
. .
.
.

— A few years ago I lost a huge Michelin star client because I mentioned the term “license of use” to them.😧

As photographers we are the happiest helping clients showcase their products through our work.

But as soon as it comes to contracts, license, copyright, our heads begin to spin. Atleast mine does.😵‍💫

These terms are awkward and uncomfortable but important as heck.

So often photographers get asked for complete rights of photos by clients when actually all they need is the license to use.🤷🏻‍♀️
This is only one situation of miscommunication.

🎙️ In this week’s episode Rob @contractlegalease shares how food photographers & bloggers can protect their photos and intellectual property when working with clients.
(Link in bio)

Rob is a food blogger, and has been a lawyer for over 20 years— so cool, right?

He shares - 
🔥 The importance of contracts
✍🏼 What should be included in a proposal
💡 Difference between license and copyright
💰 How to include the license fee
💣 What to be wary of on social media.

Even with the most amazing clients, there are many situations where disagreement or miscommunication can occur.😖

I’ve met so many photographers who don’t use a contract. Everything is mutually agreed.🫢

Having a contract - 

🔸 Establishes the scope right from the start, no surprises on the shoot.
🔸 Protects your work
🔸 Manages accountability between both parties
🔸 Protects you from any legal implications
😎 Makes you legit!

Losing that client was a big deal but in hindsight, I think it was good cuz no one can predict the discrepancies that might arise in the project & going in without an agreement, is calling for trouble.😵

No matter where you live, how small your business is, if you work with clients, You NEED to protect your work..
…and Rob @contractlegalease tells us all about it.✌🏼

There was a very small chance that it would turn into a full-blown career.

Afterall, I had no business experience.
No savings for the investment.
No idea how to use a DSLR.
I was crazy and outta my mind to go all in.😮

If you’re a hopeless romantic like me you probably also believe that the love for what you do is invincible.
..That you’ll always have that burning passion.
.. It will always make you happy.

But the truth is that our passion is NOT invincible.😓

As someone who started a food photography business with no pressure, I had said to myself that I’d never let stress take over…else what’d be the point of leaving the corporate life.🥸

But as much as I tried, the desire to do more, perform better took over & it drove me to a state I’d never imagined.😔

I remember telling myself one day, “This is how far I was meant to go. I’ve no more energy left. I don’t have what it takes to run a business.”

I cried thinking this life creative life wasn’t meant for me.
Chapter closed.💔

It took a while to understand why that had happened & how I had ignored the signs leading to this state of breakdown.

It was burnout.❤️‍🔥

🎙️ In this week’s podcast, I’m sharing how burnout took a toll on my mental & physical health - the signs you need to watch out for as a creator.
(Link in bio)

If you’ve not been motivated to pick up your camera, been feeling stuck and taking a break has not helped ...you might be burned out.💥

Burnout is not a creative block or tiredness.
It is more complex than that.
It has the power to make us give up our deepest love, choke our creativity & make us quit.👿

It took me over 6 months & many changes in my personal & business life to start feeling the joy in photography again.❤️‍🩹

I wish I’d seen what was coming & prevented it from turning so extreme.🤛🏼

The brutality of a burnout is highly underrated & taking a break is not the answer.

If you feel like you might be missing your creative spark, make sure it’s not burnout. You don’t want to lose months of your life knowing it could’ve been avoided.💛
(🎙️link in bio)

We are blessed to have a passion like food photography. We need to protect our creativity.

We need to light the fire within 🔥 and fight the fire on the outside.💪🏼
.
.
.

For this mushroom & sesame tart prep shot I used the shallowest depth of field ever. 🤩📸

Shallow depth of field is having a small area of the photo in focus & the rest of it blurry.

It’s crazy how the words “shallow depth of field” apply to life too.🤓

Few years ago, I signed up for a half marathon. It was a night marathon & my first ever.

On that night, wave after wave, hundreds of folks began the run from the starting line.🏃🏻‍♂️

It was so crowded that I struggled to find space to run & when it finally cleared, I tried getting a lead but was blocked by a group of girls.😖

They covered the path, making it impossible to overtake & I got frustrated.
So, I said a few not-good words in my mouth, angrily stepped on the side & arrogantly overtook them.😠

I thought they needed to realise they were blocking the path, so I turned my head to give them my 😡 look…

.. and my heart stopped.😧

Those girls were from an NGO. There were 2 on either side & the girl in the center was blind. The ladies on the sides were guiding & protecting her..💛

I felt so small in that moment.
All I saw was the blocked path & not the reason behind it. My shallow dof 😕

As I continued to overtake runners, I realised that no matter how fast I ran, there were still hundreds of runners ahead of me.🤔

I could run faster than the next person, but what about those who started earlier? There was no way to win this.🚫

So I began paying attention to my own speed, trying to run each km better than the other.

It then struck me that a marathon is just like life. It’s not a race with others but with ourselves.💛

Being judgemental, comparing or competing, only frustrates us.
It shows our “shallow depth of field”. 😅

Those who succeed, run their own race.
Compete only with themselves.
Uplift & cheer other runners.
And their depth of field is infinity. 💪🏼

Shallow dof is beautiful but I’ll keep it to photography so that comparison doesn’t mushroom in my mind cuz unnecessary competition only makes our focus blurry.💛

What do you think was the dof in this photo?😀 
.
.

Has it ever happened that you said something casually & .. it actually happened!🥹

And guess what happened..

3 months later, out of nowhere, I received an inivitation to attend a food photography retreat in Florence, Italy.

ITALY 🥳

Italy will nourish my soul.📸

..but it’s happening.☺️

I was at the food photography retreat in Florence & then explored Italy on my own.
10 days of No husband, no daughter - just pasta & me 😜

You know how I was looking forward to the retreat, right?

My flights were booked.  Hotels done.  Suitcase packed..
… and guess what.. Until the day of travel, I didn’t have a visa.🥺

And cuz it’s a busy season, I didn’t get my passport in time for the flight.😱

I was devastated. Cancelled my flights, hotels.  Unpacked the bags.😔

All I could do was hope the visa would be issued in the next few days, still in time for the retreat.🤞🏼

I was anxious & checked the application online every 10 minutes.

Days passed and still no visa.
2 days to go for the retreat, still no visa.🙁

The husband said, “now it will take a miracle for you to make it.”
But I wasn’t ready to give up. I was praying.  Family & friends too.💛

When so many people put out a good thought for you, it becomes impossible for the universe to ignore.✨

& so, outta nowhere, just 36 hours before the retreat, I saw a notification that my visa was granted.
Whaaa… I jumped off my chair & began to scream. Unbelievable. The miracle had happened. I began to cry.🥹

In the next 3 hours, new flights were booked.  Hotels rebooked.  Suitcase repacked.

In 3 hours from that, I was on a flight to Italy, to the retreat - one of the most unforgettable experiences of my life.❤️

It took 30 hours (many flights), $$$$ tickets, racing to flights & not receiving my luggage when I finally landed.😫

..a feeling so precious.🥰

The universe knew I was meant to be there & the power of the prayers made it happen.

The sun was grazing the sides of that Orange cake & bowl of peaches. I had to capture it cuz my heart said so.💛

Tell me, do you consider yourself a photographer, an entrepreneur, a creator OR an artist?🤓

I introduce myself as a photographer, I’m an entrepreneur when I work with clients, and on Instagram I’m a creator .. but the artist always gets left out.😦

It was the retreat that connected me back to that artist.✨✨

At the retreat, the idea was to relax. Photography was optional but @validirose was so inspiring that it was tough not to.📸

We photographed whatever spoke to our hearts. Some photographed the villa, some photographed people and some, food.🍃

…but I felt a bit out.🙁

No tripod, tethering cable or laptop, I didn’t even style the food - how was I to create a photo? It wasn’t my rhythm.🥸

And then I realised that to create, I would’ve to tap into the artist in me. ♥️

I had to be like Michelangelo & Leonardo da Vinci.
Do we understand all their artworks?
Not really, but they’re still master artists with their work open to interpretation.😜

So what if there was no tripod, I just had “see” the art, let my heart feel it and capture through my lens, unleashing the Italian artist inside, taking liberties cuz art is subjective.😉 

Somewhere along the way I had forgotten what it was to photograph like an artist, to be unrestrained & whimsical.

When we take away fear, limitation & judgment, when we allow our hearts to take over & completely lose ourselves in the moment, we turn from photographers to artists.✨✨

This retreat reminded me that out of all, I’m first an artist & then a photographer.❤️

So you received a message from a brand interested in working with you, asking for your rates.
Excitedly, you sent your rate card..

..and never heard back?😵‍💫

And that’s why offering a rate card upfront is not the best idea & also why a discovery call in our business workflow is a great idea.😅

But how can a discovery call help us offer a competitive fee & also higher our chances of working with the brand..
..when we only have 20 minutes on that call?😮

.
🎙️ In this week’s podcast episode, I’m sharing the 3 top questions to ask a client on a discovery call. (Link in bio)

I don’t say this usually, but I curated this after 5 years of learning, getting my *** kicked, losing projects, being taken advantage of and feeling like a certain client did not deserve me.😕

These 3 questions will help - 

🤓 Streamline your client booking process.
💰 Make sure your fee is suited to the project.
😎 Make you confident about your fee.
🙌🏼 Get you pumped to work with a brand.

.
Starting a conversation with a client around money could actually make us lose opportunities.
I mean, if 2 projects are not the same, then how can the fee be the same?🤷🏻‍♀️

That’s what makes the discovery call sooo crucial. When we ask the right questions before offering our rates, it allows us to:

⚡️Understand the scope completely
⚡️Gauge whether the project fits our skills & interests
⚡️Decide what the fee should be
⚡️Give the client a chance to know us

.
🎙️ Running a business is tough. We never want to feel like we lost out or got a raw deal.
The best way is by asking the right questions upfront - in under 20 minutes.
(link in bio)

💋 As tempted as we are to ask a cute client if they’re single, it’s best to save that for another time .. or maybe never 😜

Do you have a discovery call in your business workflow? 💪🏼

This vegan panna cotta made by @julskitchen during the Florence retreat @valdirose was a testament that life rewards us in mysterious ways.🥰

You know how I got my visa miraculously in time for the retreat & within 6 hours of that, I was on a flight.

That was the easy part.🤪

When I landed, the immigration was terrifying.
There was such heavy questioning by the officer that I began to shake in nervousness. Almost detained, I never thought they’d let me go.😓

In tears, I thought the worst was over but my next flight got so delayed, I had only 15 minutes to catch my last flight to Florence.

When I asked an airport staff for the gate, she said, “You need to run. Now.”😮

All my running came to the rescue. Jacket flying in the air, I was speeding through the terminal. I hopped on to an airport buggy for a lift … but halfway the buggy battery ran out. Ha!🫢

So I ran again and this time, right into the aircraft …& the doors closed behind me.

It wasn’t over.
I arrived in Florence but my luggage didn’t.😓

2.5 hours to report my missing bags & 1 hour in the taxi queue with 300 other people, 3.5 hours later, I reached my hotel. Without luggage.😫

Next morning when I went to collect my suitcase, I was told it wasn’t there.😱
That’s it. I lost it. I fought with the officer to look ..& they found it. Imagine😵‍💫

But it took 2 hours of the most intimidating & scary experience with the airport security to finally get my luggage.😖

It was only 1 hour before the retreat that everything fell into place.🥺

30+ hours, 4 flights, $$$$ & no sleep for days, going through that experience made me realise that when life has a gift for us, it makes us work hard for it.👊🏼

If we are caught in a series of bad luck or things aren’t working in our favor, it is life prepping us for that gift.🤘🏼
And when we brave the path without giving up, life surprises us with a gift so precious, we never regret the pain of the journey.💛

The retreat was my gift & this panna cotta will forever remind me that tough times always have sweet endings.💪🏼😍
.
.

🎙️And that’s why, in this week’s podcast episode our favorite food photographer, Joanie Simon @thebiteshot shares all about pricing your work as a food photographer. (Link in bio)

She walks us through - 
💪🏼 Different ways to set our rates
💵 How to approach pricing
📸 Which projects to take up
🖌️ What to include in a proposal
🕰️ How to address overtime work

.
Money is an awkward topic, it is the toughest part to wrap around in our business esp. because it is so tough to find consistent numbers.😥

Everyone has their own system, and rightly so cuz photography fee depend on so many factors -

🌏 Your geographic location
🎥 Project requirements
💡 Usage of photos
😎 Your experience level
.. and so forth.

.
These canapé’s remind us that Fig-uring out our rates, Cracking our fee may seem Berry overwhelming & not as Rosy-mary as we think, but it is essential to have a grip on our pricing model.😅

🎙️ (Link in bio)

.. so that we can make money doing what we love, keep the joy in our work & pursue a career we dream of.😍📸
.
.
.

I was a total glutton while shooting these cheeses courtesy @tillamook @pointreyescheese @beehivecheese 🤩

That espresso & lavender rubbed cheddar totally had me drooling.🤩

Well, I’m always greedy around cheese!

One time in Paris, we were at a Michelin star restaurant for a 6 course meal.

I was in France, I had to load up on cheese ofcourse. It would be disrespectful not to.😛

So, for my 6 courses, I picked every course with some or the other cheese
..and when I chose cheese as my dessert course too, the server got uneasy, cleared his throat & asked, “you like cheese?”🥸

“She does. Can you tell?” answered the husband who had been silently chuckling away on the side.😆

Food flew out of the kitchen.
While the husband enjoyed his tartare & escargot, I dug into plates of fatty goodness. 🧀

..& by the 4th course, I could use a break.🤭

..but there was no way I could let the husband know. It was a matter of self pride. So I kept going.😥

5 courses down, my face turned yellow, looking like cheese myself.
I could hear cows, goats and sheep cheering in my head, telling me how well I had done with their cheese.😵‍💫

I think I even saw a goat walk past our table.
I was delirious.👻

And right when I reached my breaking point, the dessert arrived - a giant plate of the finest cheeses, sliced, cubed, shaped as flowers - cheese exotica😰

The husband looked at my face & fell off his chair.🤣

But it wasn’t funny anymore.
It was a time of trial, a time to stay strong & make those cows & goats proud💪🏼

I said a lil prayer and went right in.
The husband’s eyes popped out.
The server froze as he watched me eat more cheese.😳

And as I finished that last slice, I could hear the entire farm applauding.🐑🐮🐐👏🏼

The husband had to help me out of the chair & I couldn’t eat cheese for a while but such is my love..err ..ahem ..greed for it.😅

Tell me, do you also like cheese for dessert?🧀 
.
.
.

Are you making money in photography? 
If you are, you have a business.
Whoop 💪🏼

But the more important question is, how much money are you making in your business? 🫢

Are you sinking?
Or
Just bout staying afloat?
Or
Swimming in dollars?
💰

Not making enough money can be a real deal breaker. It can strain our personal relationships, make us give up our business & sometimes even our love for photography altogether.😓

.
🎙️This week on the podcast we continue our power-packed pricing conversation with the incredible, Joanie Simon @thebiteshot.😻
(Link in bio)

She talks about -

✏️ How to negotiate & increase rates.
⚓️ How to know if you’re overcharging or undercharging. 
💵 When to work for free. 
💡 Big mistakes to avoid when setting your rates.
🔥 The experience that changed the way she priced her work. It will blow your mind.

.
The love that makes us start a business, have high hopes of crushin it & make a living out of it, often disappears under the pressures of making rent, killing the happiness we once felt in our craft.😵‍💫

We keep our rates low for several reasons -
💬“I’m just starting out”
💬“I won’t find clients if I charge more”
💬“I just want more clients for now”
💬“I don’t even know what to charge”

Pricing right has many advantages but it is tough to gauge what that “right” really is?🤷🏻‍♀️

🎙️ Joanie @thebiteshot shares practical ways to find that “right number” for yourself.💪🏼
(Link in bio)

🥰 We are fortunate to feel such passion for our craft to turn it into a business. It’s important to keep that passion so that our decisions are not based on need but on the love & joy we feel for our work.💛
.

Photoshoot for the awesome @saladstopsg 🤩
.

Purple potato chips with this zaatar beetroot dip by @ottolenghi is not just an explosion of colour, but also flavour.

Sweet. Salty. Creamy. Spicy with a lil extra 🌶 for extra explosion... this dip is the bomb!💣

Following recipes is not my forte, so I switched the toppings to pomegranate, dried berries & a hint of dill.
Shhh.. please don’t tell @ottolenghi 🤫

I was so excited to shoot this that I created a concept days in advance. 
White props were chosen for the rich color, a backdrop was selected & the composition was all about that sexy beat.. I mean, beet.🕺🏻 

Grooving away I whipped up this dip. Every kernel of pomegranate was added with intent.
Next, the backdrop was placed. I was moonwalking, super confident of my concept.😎

But Lights, camera, hit shutter & I went 😵‍💫😵.
The shot looked 😖.. ahem .. nothing like what I had in mind.

I moved the lights - nah! 
Changed the camera angle - nah! 
Changed the backdrop - nah! 
Changed everything in my concept & yet, nothing worked.🤯

So, I stepped back, sipped tea & forced myself to spell out what I didn’t like about the shot.🤯

.. my eyes fell on the the white props used for the dip. It wasn’t bringing out the colour. While white worked perfectly in my concept, it did not work in reality.🤷🏻‍♀️

I quickly changed everything, switching out whites for black. 

Black wasn’t the obvious choice but .. Lights, camera, hit shutter & I went 😍😍.

There it was - my vision, the colour explosion. 
I was moonwalking again Michael Jackson style & this time also singing, “Black or White”.🤩🎤 

Sometimes our ideas are so dear to us that we fear disruption but sometimes reworking a composition or even, reshooting gets us to our vision.
It only means that we are willing to do anything to achieve our vision.👊🏼

So, if you’re ever stuck while shooting, moonwalk to the side, take a sip of tea, do the MJ spin, disrupt fearlessly & sing, “just beet it.”😉
.
.
.

While shooting these Guinness stout brownies I asked the husband to take a few behind the scenes photos with my phone.😜

When I turned, I saw him standing in the exact spot at which I’d handed him the phone and was taking videos from there.

He didn’t move an inch. It didn’t occur to him that he could move. It was as though he was fixed to the floor.😅

Ahem.. he was also a bit concerned that if he moved, the photo would change & I would not be happy.😛
So he did not move. 

Result : not so great BTS ; not so happy me.🫤

It’s the same with our tripods. 
Often we setup our tripods and begin to shoot based on what WE think is the best side of the food.

We forget that the tripod is not fixed. We can change the angle, move it up or down, go closer, move further & play around to get those flattering angles.😁

Infact, playing around with the camera before setting up the tripod is a great way to find that most photogenic side of the food.

A little bit of acrobatics goes a long way.😆

Once we find the angle that works best, we can then set up our tripod in that angle & create our shot from there.💪🏼

Having a tripod should not limit us. The tripod should assist us in achieving our vision, it should not dictate our vision.

The flexibility of our tripod or the rotation of the ballhead or the reach of the horizontal arm, should not hold us back from capturing the food in its full glory.🤭

So, the next time you’re shooting, have a little fun. Step back & forth, squat up & down, climb up a ladder & do a little dance to find the most drool worthy side of your food.🕺🏻

Work & workout together - now that’s worth some brownie points.😎😆

Do you set up your tripod first or find the Angle?💛
.
.
.

This fiery tandoori cauliflower steak took me back to the time when I did revenge photography.😈

Have you ever done revenge photography?

A year or so into photography, I was invited to bid for a Michelin star restaurant project.⭐️

While the client loved my work, they didn’t agree to the license & copyright terms. 
Result : I didn’t get the job.💔

I didn’t win that project not cuz of my skills but for my emphasis on professional practices.

I was heartbroken but also seething.😡

I was also a hotheaded newbie. I wanted to show them what they had missed by not working with me.😾

Don’t know why, but at the time it seemed important.🫤

So I made a reservation at that Michelin star restaurant.
I never carry my camera to restaurants, but that day I carried the camera & extra batteries.😤

I was in my long dress, looking elegant & delicate but my mind was playing the Rocky music.🥊

As we sat across the kitchen, my eyes fell on the Chef & the fire of revenge was stoked.😠

Like a hawk I waited & as soon as the bartender was to pour a cocktail, I grabbed the camera, dodged the servers, bumped into a few tables & made a giant leap towards the bar.🙄

The bartender was petrified by the crazy lady in his face taking photos.
The guests stared at the weird girl who almost spilled their wine.
The Chef was not happy with this crazy guest disrupting the decorum of the restaurant.😖

While I was sprinting around capturing the fire grill and cocktails, the snob servers made sarcastic remarks.😏

But your girl was on a mission. Being embarrassed was not on the agenda. Neither was acting dignified.😼

I got some terrific pictures from that photoshoot & shared them with the restaurant. They loved it but..
.. nothing.😵‍💫

Did they regret their decision?
Dunno. I’ll never know.

But I learnt 2 things about revenge photography that day -

One, it is the best teacher. Fast action, moving subjects & low light - the LIVE setting catapults our skills.💪🏼

Two, it is unnecessary.
Revenge comes from a place of hurt. It does nothing except suck away energy. It sizzles with thrill, but also puts our dignity at steak.. err..I mean stake.😅

Have you ever tried revenge photography?😁
.
.

It would be so freaky if these mussels began to laugh or the parsley began to swear as I placed them in the pan.😝

Thankfully food does not express emotions but it definitely evokes emotions.🍕
The aroma of freshly baked cake 
Or the sizzle of the summer grill 
Or the cheese pull of a pizza 

Food evokes emotions in us.🥰

And if food does that, imagine how incomplete a food photo would be if it did not evoke emotion.🥸

It might sound a bit out there but there are photography techniques that help to bring emotion to food photos.🙌🏼

🎙️This week on the podcast, the talented Suze Morrison @gourmetglow tells us exactly how to achieve that.🔥
(Link in bio)

She shares - 
😯 Why food photography is incomplete without the element of emotion
🪡 How emotion & storytelling are tied together
📸 Ways to find inspiration to catapult your photography
💥 How she broke away from a certain style of photography & it unlocked her best work

.
We get so caught up in props & compositions that we forget to convey feelings through our photos.
The idea of bringing emotion to photography doesn’t always strike us. It is either - 
😾 Ignored
😾 Underrated
😾 OR missed out.

Look at other art forms, music or painting or dance - we feel moved when we experience em.
That should be the goal with food photos too.💪🏼

Looking at a food photo should make a viewer feel something - happy or hungry or take em back to their grandma’s kitchen.😍

🎙️ Each one of Suze’s @gourmetglow works transports the viewer — the ultimate goal of a food photo. If your photography is missing something, it might be this.
(Link in bio) 

Creating beautiful photos is a given but beauty without soul or emotion is empty. And this applies to food photography too.✌🏼

How do you evoke emotion through your photos? 💛
.
.
.

Sourdough smeared with cream cheese and topped with honey & walnuts is a combination I find tough to resist.🤩

You know what else I find tough? 

- Loving Instagram these days.🥸

Gosh! What’s up with this platform. It used to be so dear to us, so special..

and now it just feels .. different 😕

What we create, how it is shared and with whom it is shared - everything is different now. Maybe that’s why so many creators have left the platform.😥

For me Instagram is about the people, the community and the conversations.
I guess that’s why you & me still show up despite our wavering faith in this platform.
It’s the connections that brings us back.💛

But it is really tough to love Instagram these days. I feel like a grumpy woman seeing how it’s changing. I feel like shouting swear words and hurling a shoe at it.😵‍💫

But then, no matter how I feel, every time I’m here & post a photo, I start smiling as I respond to your words & comments. That’s what’s Instagram to me.💛

And That’s why I plan on staying here for as long as it makes sense cuz -

✌🏼 I want to. This is where my journey started and it’ll always be special.

✨ It makes me focus on my purpose vs. the results.

☝🏼 It reminds me to stay attached to the joy of creating & sharing & to detach myself from numbers.

Easier said than done but for me these aren’t just lessons for Instagram, they’re lessons for life. I’m learning.🙃

Right now Instagram may not seem as inviting as these walnuts & honey, but showing up is a win in itself.
I do however believe that the real strength is in showing up even when no one else does.💪🏼💛

What do you feel about Instagram these days? 🤓
.
.
.

“Oh, you need a break. Take a day off.”
“Go on a short holiday. That’ll fix it.”
“We all go through it. Nothing to worry.”

Those were some of the advice I got when I was going through a severe phase of burnout last year.
I tried all. Were any helpful?
Not really.😐

Well, there is everything to worry when it comes to burnout. EVERYTHING🙀

Burnout is often mistaken as tiredness.
Yes, it is tiredness but it’s long-term, chronic fatigue.

Which means, there’s no quick fix to overcome it. Burnout takes long to set in and even longer to go away.😓

My burnout was brutal. 
I stopped photographing.
Paused the podcast. 
I was angry and irritable. 
Spent less time with family.
Had no interest in anything.
I felt lost and failed.

It took more than 6 months to reignite the creative spark and there was no one-solution that worked.💔

🎙️ In this week’s podcast episode, I’m sharing 6 steps that I took to overcome & emerge from a burnout without quitting my business or giving up photography. (Link in bio) 

I share -
😵‍💫 The myths around burnout
👎🏼 Why overcoming burnout is not a quick fix
🥊 How to get real and practical about overcoming it
⚡️ How to avoid burnout so it never returns

.
Our creative lives look so artistic & rosy on the outside but only we know the mental & physical toll it can take on us. The constant creative stimulation of making art day in & out can be exhausting.
& if we have other jobs, it’s worse.😖

The dangerous part about burnout is that it brings us on the verge of losing our passion & quitting esp. when it can be prevented and if not that, then atleast overcome.💛

🎙️ If you’ve experienced burnout more than once, it’s normal but also means that you’ve not addressed the root cause. Break free from the cycle of burnout hitting you time & again.
(Link in bio)

I always say, fight the fire of burnout & light the fire within.🔥💪🏼

Have you also experienced burnout?💛
.
.
.

Sweet Mango with fiery red chilli and sea salt - tell me you love this combination as much as I do.😍

Wednesday confession - I’m obsessed with chilli. 🙊

I put it in everything. Maybe except desserts but hold on, then there’s my favorite chocolate with chilli.😅

The husband is always embarrassed when he’s dining out with me.

I’ll go to Michelin star restaurants and ask for chilli.
The answer is usually a snobbish, “Sorry, we don’t serve chilli.”
To which I ask for hot sauce & to make it sound more gourmet I say, “Would you have housemade hot sauce.” 😛

If the request for hot sauce offends them, the housemade makes up for it 😆

Even on my trip to Italy, I needed chilli flakes on the very authentic Italian pasta.
At a restaurant in Florence, a server shook his head to the chilli request and said, “we don’t have chilli flakes but we have dried pepper.”

I nodded yes and what appeared on my table were chilli flakes.😜

My fridge has different versions of chilli from flakes to paste to sauces to pickles. 🌶️
Different chillies for different food but no meal without chilli.

The husband fears one day I’ll pickle him too.🤣

But then, what is life without a little heat, a little fire and a little kick to it.🔥

Mango with salt & chilli - yay or nay?🤩
.
.
.

One of the biggest hurdles in taking up food photography professionally is having the confidence to approach brands & accept rejections.😰

Confidence might sound a bit woo-woo but the lack of it stops us from pursuing our passion professionally and makes us doubt ourselves.

Sending a pitch, quoting for a project, delivering photos or waiting to hear back from a client - confidence plays a huge role in how we respond to situations.🥸

It is deeply embedded in everything we do as creators and business owners.

🎙️ In this week’s podcast episode, the talented Anja Burgar @useyournoodles shares all about finding that confidence.💪🏼
(Link in bio)

She talks about -
📞 The reasons creators hesitate from reaching out to brands
📸 The role of a streamlined process
👎🏼 How to deal with rejections
💰 The importance of the right fee structure

.
Our confidence is linked to the value we associate with our work & for that we’ve to make sure we address what’s needed in our skills, processes and also our mindset.💡

🔸 If we feel our skills are not good enough - we don’t reach out
🔸 Not sure our fee is competent - we quote low 
🔸 If the client says no - we doubt our abilities

.
🎙️ We can’t hold ourselves back waiting to feel “ready” OR feel beaten up because of the way a client situation turned out..

..because the more work we do, the more confident we become.😎
(Link in bio)

Have you been waiting to feel “ready” to pursue a dream project?💛

📸 Photoshoot for the awesome @theanmonresortbintan 
.
.
.

The husband celebrated a milestone birthday this past weekend. 🥳 🎂

This mango Biscoff cake wasn’t his birthday cake but the celebrations were no less special.💛

They were, however, a bit stressful for me cuz I had a surprise planned that needed a lot of work. 😅

The husband is very outdoorsy, loves hiking, biking, camping etc..
So I decided to have a camping themed surprise party for him … but since it was a milestone, had to be to extra special.🎈

So I turned it into a Glamping theme - glamorous camping ⛺️ 🤩

After crazy research I found 1 company that organised glamping themed luxe picnics. They were hired.
Every detail from colour to cutlery was discussed. Took weeks. Was similar to wedding planning. So you can imagine.😅

Since it was a surprise, I couldn’t have any sign of activity at home.
So, friends were brought into the loop. Everyday wine & supplies were delivered to their places to bring along on the D-day.🤓

To finalise the caterer, I literally took a notebook & pencil & created a table to compare the food options.
Yep, I hate excel sheets.🤢
After much deliberation, mediterranean food was selected. Phew!

In secret parallel, I created video montages from his work colleagues, family and friends. Sat for days editing, adding music etc to em.🤪

And then I did the unthinkable.

The husband is a fan of Adam Grant @adamgrant so I requested Adam Grant for a personal message for the husband. And he said Yes.😱

On the eve of the birthday, the friends & I reached the venue by the ocean. The husband was at home totally confused & clueless.
📞 I called him, asked him to get dressed, called a taxi for him & he got in, no questions asked.

The taxi got him straight to the beach & when he saw us - he was swept off his feet.☺️

✨ The evening was spent by the beach, under the stars, with loving friends, watching the video montage & watching the husband’s jaw drop as he listened to Adam Grant’s @adamgrant message for him.🥳✨

It was truly a milestone to remember. One of the toughest surprises I’ve pulled off but so worth it. ❤️🥹

PS - swipe to see the glamping theme party setup 👉🏼⛺️
.
.
.
#foodphotography #foodlove #foodartblog #lifeandthyme

I struggled with sleepless nights for months when I decided to take up food photography full-time.💔

I was continuously consumed by insecure thoughts.
Those thoughts were so deeply scary that I couldn’t say them out loud.
I was embarrassed to share them with anyone. 
I didn’t have the courage.😞

…And as much as we expect, those thoughts had nothing to do with money.

Those thoughts were about other people’s opinion of me, my reputation & what people would think of me if I left architecture to become a professional photographer.😓

I was insecure & thought that this career change would not be as reputable & respected as my architect persona.👎🏼

& then recently a food photographer asked me a question. 
When I heard it, I was shocked.

She was spelling out those exact thoughts. She took me back to a time when I wondered if I was downgrading myself by becoming a photographer.😔

.
🎙️ In this week’s podcast I’m sharing my answer to her question.
This is a raw & real topic that I’ve never spoken about before.
(Link in bio)

In this episode I share - 

😑 A recent shocking incident
😥 The question that left me dumbstruck
🫵🏼 4 Brutal truths about taking up food photography professionally
💪🏼 How to deal with those truths

.
If you’ve ever considered leaving your 9-5 to start a creative career then you most definitely have had some strong thoughts.
There are some thoughts we share and some that are so difficult that we don’t dare say out loud.😒

Doubts and insecurities are part of a creative career esp. if it is a career switch and that too, not a glamorous one but rather a bold and brave switch.
But it is important to be clear in our hearts & fight anyone who comes in the way of our dreams, even if it is us, ourselves.🥊

The question from the food photographer took me back to the time when I doubted whether food photography would be a step-down for me in life.🫢

🎙️ I was embarrassed to say it then but I’m sharing it all now. No filter.
(Link in bio)

We cannot let other people’s perceptions stop us from pursuing a career of our dreams.💪🏼

Do you also have insecure thoughts about being a photographer?💛
.
.
.
#foodphotography

I just got back from a trip to India and while this blissful daal and rice is an ode to all the drop dead delicious food I ate, something on the trip made me want to just drop dead.😵‍💫

So, this was a mom-daughter trip. No husband.

The lil toddler was the best child ever. No tantrums, no crying & the trip was smooth. No hiccups, no surprises... except..
… until it was time to ✈️

At the airport, waiting for our flight back, the daughter was exhausted from the high-energy week in india.
So, we boarded first so she could settle in & rest.😴

But as she sat, I saw her expression change. She looked at me & I knew that look.😮

Like a bolt of lighting I reached for the airsickness bag but not quick enough.💥

Before I knew I was covered in vomit.🤮
It was all over me, on her, inside my purse & on our seats.😫

Dodging the stares & playing deaf to the remarks from boarding passengers, I rushed her to the washroom.
Took a chunk of tissue to clean up but turned out the water in the tap wasn’t activated just yet.
Lovely.😠

Standing in that washroom, covered in vomit, with a howling toddler, also covered in vomit - I was in complete disbelief.😓

Thankfully the 1000 wet tissues in my bag helped.

As we stepped out of the washroom, the staff was already cleaning up and turned the seats into brand new.🙏🏼✨

I changed the daughter’s clothes but had none for myself.
While she fell asleep, I poured a bottle of sanitizer over myself & then sank into my seat with wet clothes..
…what a delight to have a 5-hour flight ahead.😖

Dirty, tired & stressed, I was on high alert incase the daughter got sick again ..& she did.

But I was so prepared that I unbelted, airlifted & landed her directly in the bathroom, multiple times during the flight.😤

10 mins for landing, I was still airlifting & sprinting.
The car ride back home wasn’t pretty either. Thank god for the extra airsickness bags.🫤

I still can’t believe how I made it through that flight.
I’ll say this - It was definitely a great way to kill time when traveling with a toddler. I didn’t even need to watch a movie plus got my workout in.
Whoop whoop😵‍💫

What’s your worst flight experience so far?😐
.
.

These grape & thyme tarts are my peace offering to God.😥

With these sweet treats, I want to request Him to be done with the horrors. 
I mean, there should be a quota or something for how many tough situations we face in a month.🥸

Because it looks like God’s put me on the “unlimited experiences package”… where I’ve been running from one nightmare experience to another.😫

You know what happened on the flight back from India, right? The daughter fell sick & threw up on me.. & I pretty much sat through the 5-hour flight like that.
That’s a pretty traumatic experience, wouldn’t you say?
Enough for a long time, right?😕

But nah, God wanted to make sure I avail every bit of that unlimited package.😵‍💫

So, 2 days after that flight ordeal, I suddenly came down with viral fever.
… and not just any viral - the most brutal viral infection I’ve ever experienced.🤒

But that wasn’t enough. To make it extra fun, it happened when the husband wasn’t around, he was on a work trip.✈️

So, I was on my own to deal with it.😔

I’d be burning up in fever, shivering all night from chills, but still be up at 5:30am with 38.5 degree fever to walk our 2xdogs, morning and evening, doing 4 walks a day & then also taking care of the toddler daughter.😥

Perhaps it was a complimentary add-on to the package🙄

Well, I’m on day 9 of the viral infection & slowly recovering now.💚

..From burning fever, losing my voice, crying with chills, coughing my lungs out, losing my taste buds, throat pain like I swallowed a needle to losing every ounce of strength, I think I’ve served my thyme.❤️‍🩹

So, dear God, please accept my peace offering & cancel the subscription I never signed up for cuz I’m done being tested on how much I can endure.

I’m ready for happy healthy days, please 🙏🏼 💛
. 
.

But today, after finding my style, many times .. & working commercially with different styles, I can say that our style can be our strength but also our weakness.😮

.

If we only create one style of photos then we can only work with clients who want that one style of photography.
Which makes it essential to question whether our style is stopping us from working with clients, or opening more opportunities? 🤔

Depending on your photography & business goals -

While photographing this grape tart with feta and thyme, I remember going through a massive phase of self-doubt.
So much that I didn’t even want to post this photo..
..but my unbelievable encounter with someone else’s self-doubt changed that.❤️‍🩹

Few years back, I was judging a photography challenge on Instagram. The theme was tough & the winning entry would receive a photography session with me. 📸

One stunning photo after the other was submitted. They were so good that it took me 2 days to choose the winners & the 🔝 entry.

The 🔝 entry was creative, artistic & spectacular.😍

Excitedly, I sent a DM to the 🔝 winner to schedule the photography session & she said she’d confirm.
I waited for weeks & months but she didn’t respond.🤔

And then suddenly, few months later, she sent me a sweet, polite apology.
when I read the message, I was shaken.😯

All this while I thought she wasn’t interested but the truth was that she was intimidated.

She didn’t feel confident about her work because she didn’t own a DSLR…
And that 🔝 photo, that winning photo - was taken it with a phone.
My jaw dropped.😱😱

How talented was she!
Sadly, self-doubt got the better of her & she waived the session.☹️

Remembering this incident gave me the courage to share my work.

... Cuz self-doubt is our biggest enemy.
It makes us miss opportunities, ignore our strengths, lets comparison creep in & we lose time doubting instead of enjoying our art & feeling proud of how far we’ve come.💔

Truth is, Self-doubt always lingers in our creative lives & never really goes away but sometimes it takes a stranger to show us the way.🙏🏼💛

How do you fight self-doubt?🤛🏼
.
.
.

Shooting Brown food with brown curry is like 2 nightmares in one.😂

I worked with these @fablefoodco chunks, not exactly the prettiest food on the planet, and that too in a brown curry, for a packaging shoot for @saladstopsg @goodfoodpeoplesg .📸😅

You can imagine how stressful that must’ve been because packaging shots are the most unforgiving. Everything is printed & all the flaws show.😛

But photography should be fun, not stressful.😍

So, here are some guidelines to work with brown saucy foods -

🥦 Don’t overcoat the food with the sauce. The main protein/veggie should be clearly visible & not covered in sauce.

🤭 Extra sauce is great to eat but the camera does not like it.

🙅🏻‍♀️ Layer the dish starting with the sauce & then the food chunks. Not the other way round.

Brush the sauce so that it looks natural & not painted on, even though that’s exactly what we do.😆

🍃 Don’t forget garnish. It’s your bestie when it comes to difficult foods.

😎 Lastly, Use your photography skills to take that styling to the next level.
Position the light to bring out the shadows & highlights of the food so we see texture & also the luscious sauce.📸

.
Don’t fret while shooting tough foods. Just construct the dish one step at a time vs. overloading it all at once on a bed of rice.🤪

Thankfully my photoshoot went well & the packaging is in print.
I hear it looks good. Phew!😅

.
📌 SAVE THIS POST so that the next time you’re shooting your nightmare foods…
..whether it’s white on white or brown on brown or black on black — do it like a boss 🤩✌🏼

What’s your nightmare food?🥸
.
.

What do you do when it’s Autumn and Fall for the rest of the world but you’re sitting in the tropics in shorts & flip flops wondering how Fall feels?😜

.. Well, you create Fall for yourself by shooting food that has the all the feels, the coziness, the colours, aroma — but yet it’s out of a tropical oven 🤩

This prune Kue Lapis cake by @aanchgrill is an Indonesian specialty & made of several layers oozing with rich buttery goodness interrupted by the pop of prunes.
It is a labour of love & sometimes even called a “thousand layer cake.”😯

It’s delicious of course but what I like is that it has all the cozy feels but also the spunk of summer.😉

“Dont you miss the seasons?”
A question we get asked in Singapore all the time.😅

I definitely do.
I remember the Fall colours we had in Virginia & the snowy winter. I would sit at the sill of my beautiful apartment window & sip wine watching the frozen river.❄️
I also miss Spring cuz it reminds me of how our home would turn into a bouquet overflowing with flowers everywhere.. ah, and summers was all about vacations & mangoes.😍

I definitely love the seasons but ask me if I love going for a swim in December..😜
or sitting by the beach in January..🏖️
or better yet, ask me if I miss wearing jeans cuz in the tropics we don’t like jeans.
We like shorts.😎✌🏼

I do love the seasons but what I love more is having summer all year round.☀️
And whenever I do miss a season, all I do is create a photo that transports me into it. 💛

Do you like the seasons OR would you prefer summer all year long?😉
.
.

Honoured that this photo is part of my feature in one of the world’s leading photography magazines @whalebonemagazine in partnership with @mpbcom 🙏🏼

My favorite way to make pasta is tossing bow ties into cooked cherry tomatoes & adding a sprinkle of salt.
That sprinkle might seem simple but it’s the salt that takes the flavour to another level.🤩

A magazine feature is much like that salt.
Looks simple on the outside but to a photographer, seeing their work in print, their name amongst other talented photographers, takes their journey to another level.✌🏼

Feels magical.✨

And everytime I get this magical feeling, I think of the cleaning lady who worked for us.☺️

Years ago, during the early stages of my photography career, we had a part-time cleaning lady.

That woman was unique & made me speechless with her kindness.

She had 3 kids back in her home country & she had given birth to none of them.
All adopted, one abandoned by a friend & another, a special child.
She worked in Singapore to send money home. That was her life.

I absolutely adored her.💛

Usually, I’d be shooting while she cleaned. She’d never say a word. Just silently carry on.

One time, I was practicing photography as usual, she was cleaning.
As she dusted, vacuumed, mopped, she observed me keenly.

I barely noticed but when I looked up, she was standing right next to me with her mop.
I looked at her & she began to smile.

And then with an angelic expression she said, “One day someone will discover you.”❤️

And then she turned around & continued to clean.😮

I forgot all about the incident but within a few weeks of that I had clients reaching out to me.

And soon after, I had my first magazine feature in a global food magazine & also made it to the cover of the magazine.🥹

From then on, every time I have such magical experiences, I think of her & get goosebumps.

She taught me never to hold back from wishing someone well because genuine goodwill is way too powerful

..& I learnt it in a way I’d never imagined.🥰

Whether it’s salt or goodwill, don’t be stingy.
You never know how a simple sprinkle can send the most powerful message into the Universe & change someone’s life forever.💛✨
.
.
