This eton mess is made with strawberries, meringue kisses & lush coconut yogurt.
If you’re thinking I went with yogurt instead of cream for health reasons, ahem.. not so much 😅

I love eton mess & a few years ago, decided to make it for the first time for a dinner party.
It‘s forgivingly messy - I thought.

Now, Singapore is humid. To make food stay in shape is a struggle. Imagine keeping meringue crisp & cream stiff an entire evening.😰

To make sure the textures were perfect, I decided to make the dessert on the spot once dinner was done.
“It’s all about crushing meringue & whipping cream — easy-peasy.”
So I prepped the strawberries & left the rest for later.😎

The dinner went well.
With wine in my veins, I got cracking - literally.
I’d bought giant meringues, more solid than rocks & had to use a ladle to break em up. Took some muscle strength & lots shoulder workout.😤

Next was the pain-in-the-neck-cream.
The kitchen was crazy hot. Whipping wasn’t working. I had to shove the already chilled bowl in the freezer to get colder & then whip the heck outta the cream.
More workout. More arm strength. Exactly what I needed at that time, burning calories before taking more in.😥

Inspite of that HIIT drill, everything was taking longer than expected. Time was not my friend.
By the time I began arranging the dessert the strawberries had turned limp, floating in a kind of watery syrup. Arghh!🤯

It was definitely a mess & not so forgiving.😐

An Eton mess of sloppy cream, hard rock meringue & gooey strawberries was served to the guests that night & I swore never to make it again. ..
.. but I did.
This time with a sturdy twist & no upper body workout 🙌🏼

I make both kinds of Eton mess, the traditional & untraditional version, but the one thing I never do is making it on the spot cuz I prefer my workouts in the gym, not the kitchen.😆

What’s been your dessert disaster?😉
.
.
.

When I joined architecture school, it was the era of large drawing boards, long rulers called parallel bars and hand drafting with pencils of different grades.✏️

I remember, on my first day I was tying, pinning & setting up my sheet on the drawing board, when the professor walked up to me & said something I’ve never forgotten.

The first thing I was ever told in architecture school was that - “Every line has a meaning”.✍🏼

I followed that through my architecture career and brought that to photography too, because it’s so relevant.

Every photo has a meaning, a purpose.🔥

That purpose can vary but it is our duty as photographers to create photos that move the viewer to take some sort of action.

And it does not require any overthinking. It just needs us to be intentional in our photography decisions so that the photo looks intentional & serves a role.🤓

🎙️In this week’s podcast, I’m sharing how to create compelling photos without spending hours. (Link in bio)

✨ Why we need to create impactful photos
✨ How to streamline our photography process
✨ When do our photos miss the mark
✨ What hooks viewers to our photos without bouncing off

.
Our photo can make any impact we want. We just need to know the purpose of that photo so we can create it as per that role.

A photo’s purpose can be anything -
😌 Fulfil our passion & bring joy
🤗 Inspire others
😎 Portray a brand’s product to make a sale
🧐 Promote our recipe & food blog
😅 Enrich our portfolio…Etc.

Deciding the purpose before shooting makes it easy to take creative decisions during the process & results in an impactful photo.📸

Skipping steps or a part of the process makes our photo miss the mark & not serve the role it was intended for.👎🏼

As counterintuitive as it sounds, it is totally possible to have a workflow that saves time, is efficient and also maximises the impact of our work.💛
🎙️ Tune in to learn how (link in bio)

Unusual but delicious combo so, I had to post it here.😍

Tell me, how often do you post on Instagram?

You know it’s not always easy to find the time to post. I sometimes skip posting ..cuz of work, the podcast & sometimes other commitments.🤷🏻‍♀️

The first time I ever skipped posting, I thought the earth would shake & sky would fall. 
.. but nothing really happened. Ha, weird.🤭

The problem is how everyone talks about posting regularly & how it is essential to grow on Instagram.
I’ve always wanted to post more often but I know it’s not realistic for me.

I know many amazing content creators who post everyday & have grown tremendously.💛

And every time I feel I’m not doing enough, I look at everything else I’m working on & remind myself that our journeys are completely different. The comparison isn’t fair or necessary.✌🏼

In fact, I was once told that I wouldn’t grow on Instagram by posting only twice a week. I decided to be ok with it because my focus was to build a photography business.. and building anything takes effort.🙃

Fighting insecurity, I have continued to post at my pace. If can’t, no fret. I return & pick up where I left off.

So, if you ever feel the pressure to post more than you can sustain, try not posting for a while. Test it out. See what happens.
I promise you the earth will not shake & the sky will not fall.😅

In fact, once we take away the pressure of posting, creating content is a piece of cake & posting at our own pace, is the cherry on top.. or on the side.😜

Do you take the pressure of posting or is it a piece of cake?💛
.
.
.

I love cooking but selectively. 
In fact, one of my favourite desserts to make is this mango kheer (milk pudding). We get mangoes all year round so, this summer delight easily turns into an autumn treat.😁

This kheer is a labour of love & I love spending hours making it.. but I love spending even more time photographing it.✌🏼

You know when someone says “one thing led to another” - believe them. It really is true. 

One thing does lead to another.

My love for cooking led me to photography & I’ve spoken to several photographers who have the same story.💛

When someone asks, “did you always love photography?”
I say, “Nope”
“Then how did you get into photography?”
“Because I always loved food” 

My love for food made me cook..
.And my love for cooking led me to photography.

When we allow life to take its natural course & we take leaps of faith to go with it, life leads us to exactly where we need to be.

I never considered a career connected to food even though my whole life revolved around food.
I was just an architect who loved food.
And then while taking a short break from my architectural job, I began to cook a lot cuz I had missed it in my demanding architect’s life.🏗️

And look what happened.
Cooking made me want to photograph my food.
& Phone photos made me want to use a DSLR & suddenly we had a business.
One thing led to another… leading me to where I was meant to be.🥹

So today, I spend hours cooking kheer but I spend even more time photographing it because it was meant to be.😉

So if you feel a tug towards something, give it a chance. Whether it’s towards a bowl of kheer or the life of your dreams, that tug is probably the Universe leading you to where you’re meant to be ✨✨
.
.
.

Who makes fresh pasta at home?
Not me 🤭

We had the amazing Giulia @julskitchen teach us pasta making during the food photography retreat in Florence this past summer.😍

It was supposed to be a pasta making workshop but when 10 food photographers are presented with such a beautiful setup, you know what happens -
~ the kneading gets swapped with the camera and the only sound in the room is of shutter buttons going click click click.😂

That’s exactly how the session went .. we were excited to witness every step of the process because the camera was loving it so much.👻

I’d never photographed fresh pasta before. In fact, I’d never seen pasta being made the true Italian way.✨

I’d also never seen 10 food photographers standing across the table from Guilia, elbowing each other, pushing here, nudging there, climbing on chairs, crawling under the table & doing everything possible to capture that egg drop & water pour & flour shower.😜

That day I realised that you can take a food photographer to beautiful Italy, bring them to mesmerising Florence, invite a renowned chef, put the most exotic pasta in front of them, but all they’ll care about is, “where is the light coming from.”
🤪

Swipe to see us “making pasta” with our cameras 📸👉🏼

Less than a week to go for Diwali 🪔 & for my milestone birthday 🎂🥳 & I’m already in my stretchy pants gorging on this gorgeous Indian flavoured Ras Malai Tres Leches Cake..✨

It’s almost embarrassing to admit that in the beginning I didn’t know how to pronounce tres leches correctly.🤭

I used to keep the ‘s’ silent and pronounce it as tre leche cake.
Don’t you laugh.😂
We all have foods that we learnt to pronounce correctly a little late in life.

I ate my first tres leches cake very late in life & its pronunciation came to me even later.
YouTube helped and now I say it in the absolute authentic Spanish accent.🤓

I remember when I was in University in Texas & went to a Mexican restaurant with friends. Obviously we wanted margaritas & one was called “The Baja special”.🍸
So I waved to the server, called him to our table & said, “can I have the Baja special?”
..pronouncing Baja with a ‘J’ instead of the correct way, Baha (j = h)
And as soon as I spoke, the entire group burst out laughing.

I was embarrassed. Ofcourse.😟

But Tis the season of Diwali.
Tis also birthday week & a huge milestone..
which means, it’s high time I let go of embarrassments.✌🏼

On this big birthday 🥳 & in the spirit of Diwali, which is all about the victory of good over evil, I’m going to work on my victory over myself, over my inhibitions.

Victory over my inhibition to -
.. share embarrassing stories
.. take big risks in life
.. & pass off as a 16 year old
~~~ my tres victory list 😉

All the firms I worked with during my architecture days were well reputed & anytime I mentioned them to others in the industry, everyone knew those names immediately.
But I wanted it a bit different.
I always wanted to make a name as a thought leader in the industry, independent of the firm I worked with.💡

My mindset was to forever try to fulfil the question -  If someone took away the name of that firm from my identity, what would be left?🤷🏻‍♀️

So, as an architect I also got into research & writing.
I would attend conferences, network with professionals, write in scholarly journals & was always working towards contributing independently to the industry vs. being an employee of a firm that had an identity in the industry.🫱🏻‍🫲🏼

But Why am I telling you this? What does this have to do with photography?📸

🎙️When I spoke to Anindya & Madhushree Basu @pikturenama about how they’d built a thriving photography business despite the social media changes, their answer reminded me of that thought process.

We talked about:
✨ Whether algorithm changes impact business
✨ When do social media numbers matter
✨ The mistakes content creators make
✨ The absolute needle moving effort that improves skill & brings business

Our discussion on social media made me go back to my thoughts about having an independent identity.

If social media disappeared tomorrow, what’ll happen?
❕Will we still be able to run our business?
❕Will we still be able to have a community?
❕Will we still be able to improve in our craft?

Social media is only one part of our creative world & there is a bigger world outside of it. The moment we step into the real world and start prioritising it, we start creating an unshakeable identity for ourselves in the industry.🔥

I was secretly giggling while shooting this thanksgiving spread for @americanclubsingapore because it reminded me of when I was living in Virginia & the CEO of our architecture firm invited me to thanksgiving dinner with his family.🤭

I wore a red dress, took a shiny bag with handpicked wine & parked 🚗 in their Autumn leaves covered driveway.🍁

And as I walked into their dining room the aroma of mulled wine filled the air.
Never shy around food I said, “I’d love a glass” & Few glasses down, I was chatting with grandpa, the kids, their friends & even the dog.
It was going well.😎

And then as we sat around the table to eat, it was time for family games.

Grandpa pulled out a giant jar of beans & we had to guess the number of beans in it.
Repulsed by anything to do with math, I broke out in sweat. I had an intelligent reputation in front of my boss & this game would certainly be the end of it.😰

As the jar was passed around, I stayed calm secretly hoping someone would drop it so it’d never reach me.🙄

All guesses were noted on a paper as the jar was passed around the table..
…& the jar finally made it to me.🫙

My head was spinning but I faked a confident face. Began counting up & down & then doing some random calculations just to look serious & then I took God’s name & wrote my guess on that paper.
Passed the jar to the next person.
Done.Phew! 🫣

There was complete silence as Grandpa checked the numbers. He pulled his spectacles down to his nose, gave us a long stare & said that the guesses were great but he couldn’t believe how accurate one guess was.
It was just 5 off from the 800 count.
And then he looked at me.
I almost choked when he took my name.😱

Whaa! That guess was mine. It was crazy. Hail the mulled wine😛

Grandpa presented me with a $20 prize & my boss gave me a proud look.
Ahem..his kids were not amused.👀

I drove out of that driveway with my reputation intact, a happy tummy & pockets full - Talk about reasons to be thankful for… including the invention of mulled wine 😜

This story always makes giggle, even in a client photoshoot, and makes me forever thankful for the gift of laughter.✨

What are you thankful for this year?💛
.
.

Among the foods that I dont share are these Pistachio cream croissants and that too when they’re served for breakfast in the Florence countryside @valdirose under a gorgeous tree with the Tuscan sun rays peeking through the leaves.😍

And when I’m in that setting you know what else happens? 

I feel as though I was meant to be born an Italian because one of the qualifications to be an Italian is an innate love for carbs..
..& oh boy, there are very few of us who wouldn’t qualify, right?🤪

But loving food is not enough, the other qualification we need is using the correct Italian pronunciation of food.🫵🏼

Do you know that the Italians have their own pronunciation of pistachio?
I had no idea.🤷🏻‍♀️

If you pronounce pistachio with a “shee”, join the club of “inauthentic Italian word pronuncers”

The Italians actually spell pistachio as pistacchio with 2 Cs & pronounce it pistakio much like Pinocchio.🤓

Everytime I went to a cafe in Italy, I asked for espresso instead of cappuccino & got a big proud smile because cappuccino is not coffee for Italians.😁

Everytime I went cold cuts shopping I pronounced porchetta as Porketta, the true Italian way & got extra goodies in my bag.

When I went for pistacchio gelato and pronounced it their way, I got extra ice cream & a topping of cream.🍦

And when I went for a run 🏃🏻‍♀️ one morning in Rome an Italian guy shouted from across the street, “bravo Bella bravo”👏🏼

I mean, I felt so Italian at heart, so qualified to be an Italian that I almost changed my name to Dyuticha .. ..oops sorry.. to Dyuticcha 😜

But the truth is, I can share names, I can share being Indian & Italian, I can also share pronunciations, but the one thing I can’t share is a pistachio cream croissant.
I definitely don’t qualify there.🥐 😛

Tell me, how do you pronounce pistachio?😅
.
.

I sabotaged my own career take off because I refused to accept my new identity.

I transitioned from a corporate life to a creative life at my own will and yet, I had a tough time accepting it.

I wanted it so badly & yet, I was fighting myself to accept myself.

These are the harsh realities of moving from a life you’ve spent years building to a life you want to live… that transition isn’t always easy.😤

I was once asked in an interview what was the biggest challenge I faced in starting a photography business and my answer was .. overcoming myself.❤️‍🩹

The biggest hurdle to our success is often we ourselves. We want to live life by the rules but also be a rebel.
We want the high flying tag but also be a free spirited creative.
We want to pursue our passion but also fear the tough life.🫢

We are lucky that the universe has chosen us to lead a creative life. Not everyone is chosen, you know. 
My husband for one would never be chosen. He was chosen for a corporate life & he loves it.😅

We are the privileged ones to be part of the Universe’s creative circle & we should cherish it.. as much as we should cherish our passion for it.✨

It takes courage to leave behind a thriving career to follow your heart.
If you’re at that threshold, don’t make the same mistake I made.
💛 Give life a fair chance.
💛 Give your passion a fair chance.
💛 Give yourself a fair chance.

Truth is, we never need to leave our past behind. If we didn’t have that past, we would never have this present. It is our past that brings us to our present & when we take that rich past with us, it makes our present even more powerful.💪🏼

Often time our biggest battle is within us. It might seem like the easiest to overcome but is the toughest.
✔️ If we want to be photographers, let’s start by calling ourselves that.
It all starts by accepting ourselves as who we want to be because if we don’t, no one else will either..
.
.

We celebrated our 12th wedding anniversary on Monday. ❤️
We’ve known each other for over 30 years now & this photo is my artistic rendering of our love story✨✨

This year we had special plans to celebrate but the husband fell sick & we cancelled everything.😑

On the quiet anniversary evening while having pizza for dinner I reminisced about the first time I saw him.

I met him in 6th grade, and he was my arch rival.
Academic topper, awesome singer, cricket freak & a wonderful person — ugh! So many reasons to hate him.😛

We sat on opposite sides and never exchanged a single smile. 
I did, however, often peek into his lunch box loaded with scrumptious parathas (flat bread).🤤

Biting into my sandwich, I’d often drool over his parathas.. until one day I shoved my self respect & walked up to him offering an exchange, not of smiles, but of his paratha with my sandwich.
And he agreed😌

That was the beginning of exchanging smiles, gifts and letters. .. letters we wrote to each other for years.✍🏼

But then we moved to different cities & lost touch.
It broke our hearts.
We were forever trying to find each other, through common friends or Google.
7 years passed and we didn’t find each other.💔

.. and then one night, when I was in undergrad architecture school, my cellphone rang.📲

I said, “hello”
Hearing the voice on the other side, my heart skipped a beat.
I couldn’t speak for the next few minutes.

He had found me.
We had found each other.💕

While it’s a good ending, it was the beginning of our tough long-distance relationship that lasted another 7 years.💔
We lived in different continents for 7 years at the mercy of good internet.

But I didn’t want to have an online wedding & cyber kids, so I moved from America to Singapore only to be with him..🥰

I often wonder what would’ve happened had he not called that night.
But I guess the universe knew that the two romantics who shoved their self-respect for food were meant to be together😬

The celebration this year may not have been fancy & that’s ok because I’m just grateful that there are no more heart breaks in our story.❤️
.
.

How many times have you wondered if a new camera will improve your photography?
How many times have you wanted the same lens your favourite photographer uses?
How many times have you debated whether to buy flash or continuous lights?

Buying photography equipment is not easy. It’s almost like a life decision for us.😅
Photography equipment is expensive $$$$ & selecting the right equipment can be intense & and bit overwhelming.
So many choices do not make it easy.

So how do we decide what we need, when we need it & how do we buy it without the headache of a long-drawn 1000-questions decision making process?🥸

🎙️In this week’s episode I’m sharing how to save time and money, 2 of our most precious commodities, while investing in photography gear.🤩
(Link in bio)

I share -
😎 A smart way to know what gear we need
😎 A strategic way to make sure what we buy is 100% useful
😎 A simple way to make decision-making easier

Ask any photography & they’ll definitely have a wish-list of equipment they would like to own.
Ask why they haven’t bought it yet, they’ll say, “Budget.”
The rest will say, “I’m saving up for it.”🤭

That’s how important and dear photography gear is to us.
We may not love to shop for clothes & shoes but take us to a photo store & watch us turn into starry-eyed 5 year olds.😜

Buying photography equipment should not be a dilemma causing & headache-inducing process.
It should also not burn a hole in our pockets without being worth it.🤑

🎙️ One wrong choice can set us back hundreds and thousands of dollars. 
It can also set us back in our confidence and in feeling skilful — that’s how important it is to make our equipment choices wisely. Tune in to learn an easy way to do so.

A few years ago during one of my shoots @americanclubsingapore a bartender came up to me and said, “We sold over 200 glasses of this cocktail that you photographed for us last month.”
And he showed me the photo of this Pomegranate Margarita that I shot for their festive promo.😍

He then told me how their cocktail sales had gone up because of the photos.

I couldn’t dance in front of them but in my mind I was grooving.✌🏼

These words are gold for us photographers cuz we all know that in photography, there isn’t much acknowledgment or validation.

In fact, no one knows who’s behind the drool worthy photos that make them order that chocolate cake online or choose that Big Mcburger by looking at the poster.🍔

Few weeks ago, we were at a friend’s & some of their other friends joined in.
When they heard I was a food photographer, they questioned what it was. I tried to explain but they weren’t getting it.🤷🏻‍♀️

So I said, “when you walk into a mall & see those huge screens with food photos - that’s what food photographers create.✨

When you’re standing to order your salad & looking at the colourful salad photos on the menu board - that’s the work of a food photographer.✨

When you’re researching a restaurant online & see delicious photos on their website that compel you to make a reservation - that’s the creation of food photographer”✨

They understood immediately.😅

Truth is, food photographers are almost never at the forefront.
So, when photographers hear words like the bartender’s, it’s a huge validation cuz it’s based on real results
- We made the food look so enticing that a viewer couldn’t resist it & bought it.
200 glasses of this cocktail sold & the client’s sales went 💰💰— I mean what more can we ask for.🤩

But the truth is also that validation or not, visibility or not, acknowledgment or not - no matter what, we always do our job with crazy passion so that someone somewhere chooses a pomegranate margarita just by looking at the photo.😍
.
.
.
.

The first time I ever had an enquiry for a cookbook shoot project, I was totally clueless.
I had no idea how such a large project would come together, leave alone pricing for it.😧

When I read the brief I made a mental calculation that the fee was approx. $5000.
But I knew I needed to reach out to someone who could advise me.😥

So I reached out to friend food photographer & she patiently answered all my questions.
And you know what I realised after getting that clarity?

That $5000 was a massive underquote .. it was easily a $12000 project.😱😱

And do you know who that friend was?😍
It was none other than the talented Diana Muresan @craft_and_muse who came to my rescue.💝

🎙️This week on the podcast we continue our conversation with Diana Muresan @craft_and_muse about all the tricky details of cookbook shoots and she shares all with complete transparency.
(Link in bio)

We talk about how to - 
✨ Pricing the project confidently
✨ how to be Credited in such projects
✨ Curveballs to expect
✨ How to cater for contingencies
✨ How to keep cookbook shoots profitable

It is one thing to not know the project fee but to underquote & then get the job …
it can be detrimental to our confidence, passion, and the desire to do a good job on the project.
Imagine how unappreciated and undervalued it would make us feel.😓

🎙️ It’s always a good idea to know what it takes to execute different kinds of projects so that if there’s ever an opportunity, our decision to take or leave it is based on our interest, instead of our lack of knowledge about it.💪🏼💪🏼
(Link in bio)

Happy new year with this tropical Vegan Mangosteen smoothie. ✨✨

I’m back from our holiday in New Zealand & it was one of our best vacations ever. A wonderful end to a year & beginning of another.☺️

Here on IG I loved reading how 2023 was an overall successful year for most creatives, for the most part.
Obviously that made me think what my achievements were and whether 2023 was pivotal.🤔

The answer I got from myself was not what I was expecting.😲

Yes, I spoke at a conference, attended a retreat in Italy, connected with 100s of new photographers, worked with some cool brands & magazines.

While all that was great, I think my biggest highlight of 2023 was to embrace stillness - not an answer I was expecting.💛

After my brutal burnout in 2022 when I was ready to quit, 2023 taught me how to create a long-term sustainable business workflow without overwhelm & overwork.📸

I learnt how to move forward but in a steady way, no crazy jumps, no life-changing leaps, just putting one foot in front of the other.

That itself is a huge deal.✌🏼

2023 helped me get a grip on my business. There were times when I felt behind, I wanted to do more but I just couldn’t.
Now I know why…

Because the Universe was making sure I had a good foothold on everything before adding more.✊🏼
It was making sure I was securing what I already had before making big leaps that could’ve burnt me out again.

That feeling of stillness & yet moving forward was 2023’s biggest gift to me.🥰

So, if you don’t have big achievements or success stories from 2023, please remember that..
There is growth in stillness
There is power in steadiness
There is promise in slowness ❤️

Shape 2024 your way - Fast & furious or slow & steady. You decide. It’s your year, you own it.
Cheers! 🍸🍸
.

Have you ever doubted your skills?
Made sacrifices to pursue your passion for photography?
Had to convince someone about how promising a food photography career is?

Truth is, being a creative professional comes with challenges.😓

Living a creative life esp. as a business is tough. Half the world doesn’t see it as a serious profession.
And when we learn to deal with that, our own insecurities come up.

What I’ve realised over the years is that our love & passion for photography is not enough to keep us in it.😱

There has to be a stronger reason, one that is deep-rooted in purpose and higher fulfilment to make all our struggles & hard work worthwhile and also for us to feel more secure as creative professionals.

🎙️ In this week’s podcast, I’m sharing how to find that higher meaning and purpose in food photography, something not talked about.

Comment “higher purpose” below & I’ll send you the link to tune in.

I share - 
✨ why we need a higher purpose
✨ How to make our creative lives more meaningful
✨ how my thinking changed once I discovered this purpose
✨ how a small simple step can change your life
.

Just by being photographers we can - 
Change someone else’s life
Build a better life for them
Support their families 
Help them follow their dreams💛

Just by doing what we do we can make an impact & a huge difference in the world.👊🏼

The best part is that in turn, it takes away our self-doubt, makes us more confident & secure and bolsters our own faith in what we do - So much to give & gain by tapping into that bigger purpose.❤️

I can guarantee that once you find it, you’ll never see food photography the same way, and no one around you will either.✌🏼
